title: The Northcott Boundary: Hodge Level and the MP/LPO Frontier for Mixed Motives (Paper 62, Constructive Reverse Mathematics Series)
description:
Paper 62 of the Constructive Reverse Mathematics series. We identify the sharp boundary between Markov’s Principle (MP) and the Limited Principle of Omniscience (LPO) for decidability of Ext1(ℚ(0), M) in the DPT framework.

The boundary is controlled by the Hodge level of the motive: when all nonzero Hodge numbers satisfy |p − q| ≤ 1, the intermediate Jacobian is an abelian variety, the Northcott property transfers via the Abel-Jacobi isomorphism, and decidability requires at most MP. When some hp,q ≠ 0 with |p − q| ≥ 2, the intermediate Jacobian is a non-algebraic complex torus, the Northcott property fails structurally, and decidability escalates to LPO.

The main novelty is Theorem C (No Weak Northcott): no intermediate condition prevents the LPO escalation. Each degree-d slice of the cycle space is BISH-decidable, but quantifying over all degrees requires LPO. The proof is an explicit constructive reduction.

Combined with Papers 60–61, the full DPT hierarchy for mixed motives is governed by three invariants: the analytic rank r, the Hodge level ℓ, and the effective Lang constant. As a consequence, cycle groups on Calabi–Yau threefolds with h3,0 ≥ 1 — the compactification spaces of string theory — are structurally LPO, placing the string landscape beyond the reach of any search procedure.
